llm_response.description: The retinal fundus image shows multiple intraretinal hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are no signs of neovascularization or vitreous hemorrhage. No significant venous beading or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) are observed.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear optic disc with no signs of neovascularization. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, or cotton wool spots. The retinal vessels appear normal without any venous beading or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities.

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of hard exudates in the inferior temporal quadrant. There are no signs of microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, venous beading, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA), or neovascularization.

The retinal fundus image shows a clear optic disc with no signs of neovascularization. The macula appears normal without any exudates or cotton wool spots. There are no visible microaneurysms, hemorrhages, or venous beading. The retinal vessels appear normal without any signs of intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA).

The retinal fundus image shows the presence of neovascularization near the optic disc, indicating proliferative diabetic retinopathy. There are also areas of preretinal hemorrhage visible in the inferior region of the retina.

The retinal image shows multiple intraretinal hemorrhages, particularly in the central region. There are also several microaneurysms visible. No signs of neovascularization or vitreous hemorrhage are present. There is no evidence of venous beading or intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA).
